definitions.definition: to suppose that something is true, although you do not have actual proof
definitions.sensetop: presume (that)…it is presumed that…presume somebody/something to be/have something

examples.text: They are very expensive, I presume?
I presumed (that) he understood the rules.
Little is known of the youngest son; it is presumed that he died young.
I presumed him to be her husband.
I had presumed wrongly that Jenny would be there.
I presumed that he understood the rules.
They presumed that she wouldn't be interested in the job because of the low salary.

definitions.definition: to accept that something is true until it is shown not to be true, especially in court
definitions.sensetop: presume somebody/something + adj.presume somethingpresume somebody/something to be/have something

examples.text: In English law, a person is **presumed innocent** until proved guilty.
We must presume innocence until we have proof of guilt.
We must presume them to be innocent until we have proof of guilt.

definitions.definition: to accept something as true or existing and to act on that basis

examples.text: The course seems to presume some previous knowledge of the subject.

definitions.definition: to behave in a way that shows a lack of respect by doing something that you have no right to do

examples.text: I wouldn't presume to tell you how to run your own business.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French presumer, from Latin praesumere ‘anticipate’ (in late Latin ‘take for granted’), from prae ‘before’ + sumere ‘take’.
